result.execSummary:
The defendant Abraham Valdez-Mondragon was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Invade Privacy - Use Surveillance Device, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 942.08(2)(a).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.addlTxt:
Defendant Abraham Valdez-Mondragon in court with attorney Paul Steven Screnock.  Chad A. Hendee appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  
Interpreter Enrique Soria appears in court; sworn by the clerk.
  Atty Hendee states plea agreement.  Atty Screnock agrees.  Defendant agrees.  Atty Screnock enters an Alford Plea.  
  Court questions defendant regarding plea. Advises of Constitutional Rights and elements of the charge.  Court finds plea made knowingly, voluntarily & Intelligently.  Court relies on the criminal complaint for a factual basis.  

BY THE COURT:  Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charges.  Court accepts defendant's plea and finds defendant guilty.

  State has complied with victim notification requirements.  Atty Hendee gives the court and the defense a victim impact statement. Atty Hendee asks the court to follow the recommendation.
Atty Screnock makes sentencing arguments.

BY THE COURT:  Court orders 15 days in the Marquette County Jail w/huber; consecutive to any other sentence
  Report on or before November 1, 2016 by 7:00pm, clean & sober.
Eligible for Electronic Monitoring
Court Costs = $243.00
DNA Sample + $200.00 Surcharge
bond to be applied; balance to be returned to the party that posted it.
Return date on October 20, 2016 at 01:45 pm.

Defendant Abraham Valdez-Mondragon in court with attorney Paul Steven Screnock.  Chad A. Hendee appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  
Interpreter Enrique Soria appears in court; sworn by the clerk.
Atty Hendee states that he did meet with Atty Screnock and at this point there is no resolution.
Atty Screnock asks for time to go over the offer with his client and with Atty Hendee.

BY THE COURT:  Set for Return.
bond continued.  Return date scheduled for October 20, 2016 at 01:45 pm.

Court questions the defendant.  Defendant did not get a copy of the criminal complaint.  Officer takes the defendant outside the courtroom to serve a copy.
  Defendant now received a copy of the criminal complaint & waives it's reading. 
BY THE COURT:  Warrant quashed; based on defendant's appearance in court.

  Court advises defendant of right to an attorney.  Defendant understands.  Court finds probable cause to support the charges.

  BY THE COURT:  Court enters a Not Guilty plea on behalf of the defendant.

Court questions the defendant.  Defendant wants to get an Attorney.

  Interpreter Enrique Soria appears in court; sworn by the clerk.
Atty Hendee states that the defendant appears on a warrant that he failed to appear for an April 11th hearing.
Court confirms address.  Defendant gives new address.  Court questions the defendant as to his non-appearance.  Defendant did not get the notice from his dad's house. 
  Return date scheduled for June 16, 2016 at 01:45 pm.
